Did French authorities know cement company Lafarge was funding terrorist groups?
subhead: A French court sought on Thursday to shed light on the persistent suspicion of state complicity in the Lafarge terrorist financing case. Between the proven lie of a Lafarge executive to a diplomat and the timely forgetfulness of an ambassador, the fog has only thickened.

2026 World Cup: France faces tough group with Norway, Senegal and a play-off winner
subhead: France now knows its group stage opponents for the next World Cup, which will take place from June 11 to July 19, 2026. Drawn into Group I, Les Bleus will face stiff competition but will benefit from limited travel.

title: Trump takes aim at Europe in new security strategy
subhead: The new National Security Strategy, published early on Friday, does not name specific movements or political parties, but clearly demonstrates the Trump administration's desire to see its policies implemented in Europe, especially regarding immigration.

title: Frank Gehry, the most celebrated architect of his time, dies at 96
subhead: The lauded architect designed such striking buildings as the Walt Disney Concert Hall in Los Angeles and the Guggenheim Museum in Bilbao.

title: France's Théâtre du Soleil faces audit following allegations of sexual violence
subhead: The French Ministry of Culture has recommended an independent audit of Ariane Mnouchkine's troupe, which has been shaken by multiple testimonies from former employees and volunteers.

title: Ivorian youth are swept up in a retro craze
subhead: Music and fashion from the 1960s and 1970s, once symbols of Côte d'Ivoire's post-independence economic and cultural boom, are experiencing an unexpected resurgence in popularity.

title: Iran's independent cinema in full revolt: 'With Woman, Life, Freedom, a major barrier was broken'
subhead: Galvanized by the movement that emerged after the death of Mahsa Amini in September 2022, more and more filmmakers are dating to shoot outside any official framework. In a country where film production is a state matter, their films, made and distributed clandestinely, show Iranian society as it really is.

title: 'With 'The American Revolution' series, director Ken Burns warns against the tendency to judge heroes of the past through the eyes of the present'
subhead: In a spectacular documentary, the filmmaker advocates for a nuanced and diverse understanding of the history of the American War of Independence against the British Crown – a perspective that does not sit well with all Republicans, explains Le Monde's Corine Lesnes.
